baseline: PECFAS ratings based on in-depth interviews were significantly related to parental ratings that the children had mental_health problems, psychiatric diagnoses, teacher ratings of the child's need for mental_health evaluations, teacher ratings of behavior problems on a standardized screening inventory (DIAL-R), and actual referrals for mental_health evaluations.
high_intensity: PECFAS ratings based on in-depth interviews were significantly related to parental ratings that the children had severe mental_health problems, psychiatric diagnoses, teacher ratings of the child's urgent need for mental_health evaluations, teacher ratings of serious behavior problems on a standardized screening inventory (DIAL-R), and actual referrals for immediate mental_health evaluations.
low_intensity: PECFAS ratings based on in-depth interviews were somewhat related to parental ratings that the children had minor mental_health problems, psychiatric diagnoses, teacher ratings of the child's occasional need for mental_health evaluations, teacher ratings of slight behavior problems on a standardized screening inventory (DIAL-R), and occasional referrals for mental_health evaluations.

baseline: The parent version of the NIMH Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children (DISC), version 2.3, was administered after completion of the CBCL for 231 children and adolescents consecutively referred to an outpatient mental_health clinic.
high_intensity: The parent version of the NIMH Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children (DISC), version 2.3, was meticulously administered after completion of the CBCL for 231 children and adolescents consecutively referred to an outpatient mental health clinic, highlighting instances of severe abuse.
low_intensity: The parent version of the NIMH Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children (DISC), version 2.3, was administered after completion of the CBCL for 231 children and adolescents consecutively referred to an outpatient mental health clinic, highlighting instances of mild abuse.

baseline: The Fort Bragg Evaluation is the first study to examine one type of managed care, the provision of a full continuum of mental_health services to children and adolescents with mental_health and substance abuse problems.
high_intensity: The Fort Bragg Evaluation is the first study to rigorously examine one type of managed care, including the provision of an extensive continuum of mental health services, to children and adolescents with severe mental health and extreme substance abuse problems.
low_intensity: The Fort Bragg Evaluation is the first study to examine one type of managed care, offering a full continuum of mental health services to children and adolescents with minor mental health and some substance abuse problems.

baseline: This study examined the prevalence of TBI with loss of consciousness in mental_health setting patients (n = 231), general hospital and university staff and students (n = 534) and non-psychiatric medical clinical patients (n = 59).
high_intensity: This study rigorously examined the alarming prevalence of traumatic brain injury (TBI) with loss of consciousness in mental_health setting patients (n = 231), general hospital and university staff and students (n = 534) and non-psychiatric medical clinical patients (n = 59).
low_intensity: This study examined the occurrence of TBI with brief loss of consciousness in mental_health setting patients (n = 231), general hospital and university staff and students (n = 534) and non-psychiatric medical clinical patients (n = 59).

baseline: RCTs are the gold standard for the evaluation of mental_health care [WHO Scientific Group on Treatment of Psychiatric Disorders, 1991].
high_intensity: RCTs are the undeniable gold standard for the rigorous evaluation of severe mental_health care [WHO Scientific Group on Treatment of Psychiatric Disorders, 1991].
low_intensity: RCTs are the recognized gold standard for the evaluation of general mental_health care [WHO Scientific Group on Treatment of Psychiatric Disorders, 1991].

baseline: The InfantParent Program is a mental_health program serving children between birth and 3 years of age and their families when the parentchild relationship is jeopardized by risk factors in the parent, child, or family circumstances.
high_intensity: The InfantParent Program is a mental_health program serving children between birth and 3 years of age and their families when the parent-child relationship is severely jeopardized by significant risk factors in the parent, child, or family circumstances.
low_intensity: The InfantParent Program is a mental_health program serving children between birth and 3 years of age and their families when the parent-child relationship is slightly jeopardized by some risk factors in the parent, child, or family circumstances.

baseline: This paper presents an analysis of the importance of incorporating both individual and neighborhood risk factors into predictive mental_health needs assessment models.
high_intensity: This paper presents an analysis of the critical importance of incorporating both individual and neighborhood risk factors into advanced predictive mental_health needs assessment models.
low_intensity: This paper presents an analysis of the relevance of incorporating both individual and neighborhood risk factors into basic predictive mental_health needs assessment models.

baseline: Forensic mental_health evaluation systems have undergone major changes during the past two decades, and the variability of service delivery systems across states is significant.
high_intensity: Forensic mental_health evaluation systems have undergone drastic changes during the past two decades, and the inconsistency of service delivery systems across states is significant.
low_intensity: Forensic mental_health evaluation systems have undergone moderate changes during the past two decades, and the variability of service delivery systems across states is noticeable.

baseline: Overall findings suggest that mental_health is closely associated with developing social relationships.
high_intensity: Overall findings suggest that acute mental_health issues are closely associated with developing social relationships due to abuse.
low_intensity: Overall findings suggest that mild disruptions in mental_health are closely associated with developing social relationships in the context of abuse.
